subject: Re: [junit] reg. JUnit
msgSnippet: ... assert methods generally take the form of expected then actual -- you have that reversed here. ... No offense, but this same basic example has been
messageBody:
On Tue, 2003-09-16 at 09:42, selgan wrote:
> Here we go:
> ------------
> /*
> * SimpleAdder.java
> */
> public class SimpleAdder {
>
> /** Creates a new instance of SimpleAdder */
> public SimpleAdder() {
> }
> /** adds two integers */
> public int add(int a,int b) {
> return a+b;
> }
> }
>
> -----------
> /*
> * SimpleAdderTest.java
> * JUnit based test
> */
> import junit.framework.*;
>
> public class SimpleAdderTest extends TestCase {
>
> public SimpleAdderTest(java.lang.String testName) {
> super(testName);
> }
> /** Test of add method, of class SimpleAdder. */
> public void testAdd() {
> SimpleAdder simpleAdder = new SimpleAdder();
> assertEquals(simpleAdder.add(4,4),8);

assert methods generally take the form of 'expected' then 'actual' --
you have that reversed here.

> // Add your test code for exceptions, etc
> fail("Exceptions not handled. Say for add (null,null), etc");
> }
>
> }

No offense, but this same basic example has been answered at least two
or three times already.

=jason
